review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2021
review.title: Working well
review.review: Mice are like shoes, so it's difficult to say what works well for everyone. I use a mouse 14+ h/day for long days at work and then what time I can have saving the universe. I've owned about every brand, both wired and wireless. My latest venture with the SteelSeries was based off a YT vid review that just happened to play. I'd been using a Razer Viper Mini for the past year and while it was a good mouse, it's just a bit too mini for me (average size hands).I've been pleased so far with this mouse. The weight is lighter than most, which I've increasingly grown to appreciate. I don't care much for wireless mice, so this wired one was my preference. The cable is ok - no kinks and with my setup, no drag/pull as I'm moving around. I already had a SteelSeries keyboard, so the software worked without issue picking up the mouse and adjusting settings. I've never had issue with SteelSeries software before, so that's been a non-issue as well.The mouse feels pretty good and has no plastic stuck on the sides like some of SteelSeries other mice. Those glued on pieces are nothing short of a mess over time as they goop out and get on your desk/hands/mouse. This mouse is all solid and is comfortable for long usage times. Clickers work well andthe wheel was surprisingly better than I feared - not exactly smoot, not horribly bumpy.Overall, I like this mouse and for the money, feel like I got a good product for the cost. I generally go through mice every 1 to 3 years, depending on how they hold up. I'm hoping this holds up to the task.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: Completely useless for my target purpose (gaming)
review.review: I've had a SteelSeries Rival 310 for a couple of years now and am perfectly happy with it, but then I found out about this model which seemed like a straight upgrade to me after watching and reading a couple of reviews. After getting it out of the box, I was excited to test it out in my favorite game, DOTA 2. Very quickly however I found out that unlike the two side buttons of the Rival 310, which are extremely easy and super natural to press, all 5 of the side buttons of the Rival 5 were exceedingly difficult and unnatural to press, and also led to mouse movement due to the force required to press the buttons. Also, my thumb had to be in a very weird and cramped position to be able to press the side buttons at all. The big forward side button was basically impossible to press, and the up/down rocker was very difficult to press as well. From the natural thumb resting position, it requires a significant movement to be able to press even the closest two ("back/forward") buttons, unlike with the Rival 310 where those buttons are basically instant-press as soon as you think about them. Therefore, this mouse is completely unusable for playing Dota 2, and I would guess any other game.I have medium to slightly large sized hands, and I would imagine someone with very large hands / long fingers, or some specific grip style might be able to use the side buttons (I am using a standard grip), but for me they are completely unusable. Again, the Rival 310 side buttons are perfectly usable so I'm unsure why they decided to move them way out of reach.The other features of the mouse are fine, as is the build quality, although I heavily dislike the default-on lighting, and the fact that the RGB lighting settings are NOT stored on the mouse itself, so if you use it with a different PC or laptop on which you don't have the SteelSeries software installed, you are forced to have your mouse glow super bright in random colors. The cable is OK too.I hope they make a "real" upgraded version of the Rival 310, with more side buttons, that are natural to reach, like the two existing ones, and not this "apparent" upgrade which is really a huge downgrade.

review.review: Mostly an MMO player here, and this has been a great mouse for me.Good quality, software's easy to use, buttons are responsive and fully macroable, and the on-board storage saves your macro choices so you can use it on any computer the same way.One small complaint is that the... coating?on the sides comes right off after a very short amount of use.I ended up peeling most of it off because it was getting unsightly in the first six months.That said, the plastic underneath is just fine, so peeling off the coating doesn't harm anything, just looks kinda grungy and the peeling coating can be an annoying feeling until you get it all off.This one's lasted me since May 2016; just recently the left-forward side button has stopped responding, though.All the other buttons are still fine.I'm given to understand that this one's out of production, which is very saddening; hopefully their new stuff is just as good.For now I'm buying one more copy of this mouse, and we'll see if it lasts me another four years!

review.title: I really want to love this mouse... EDIT
review.review: EDIT: Lowered this to a 1 star review. I have had this mouse for 8 months and the scroll wheel is already failing. Every few clicks on the downward scroll results in an upward bounce. Same reason I got rid of my last Sensei, but I had that mouse for years. Not sure what's up with the quality of their mice these days, but I'd avoid them at all costs.I had a SteelSeries Sensei RAW for years, and it was great for everything I used it for. When it finally came time to replace it, ended up buying another. But in less than 3 months, this mouse is already looking like it's headed for the trash can. In general, it functions just as well as the last one I had, but this mouse puts out a horrible, high-pitch noise when it's idle. For more than 30 seconds after you stop moving the mouse, or if you bump it, or the table shakes a bit, there is a sustained high-pitch tone that I cannot drown out. And while it's less obvious when competing with other noises, for me it is still quite noticeable, and it's driving me insane.
